g.text: situation will give rise to two noninteracting or weakly interacting magnetic sublattices. It will be interesting to
follow the evolution of two sublattices getting engaged in single magnetic lattice (Fig.
the famous Goodenough-Kanamori rule. Accordingly, we have designed a series of DPs, LaSr
respectively. Due to large crystal field splitting, the empty
orbitals of Re have much higher energy than the
manifold and do not contribute in any interatomic exchange interaction. The filled
orbital of Ni as well has less
involvement in the exchange interaction. The only possible exchange interaction that can be active between the
, will be very weak if the
angle is strictly 180°, as the overlap integral between the
becomes zero. However, finite overlap between these orbitals can be introduced by tuning the bond
angles and lattice parameters as a consequence of the doping of Sr
In our design criteria of the ordered LaSr
cations are also selected in such a way that
there are large differences in their charge and ionic radii, in order to achieve complete
do fulfill the above criteria. Detailed magnetic measurements
indicate curious evolution of magnetic states as a function of doping. For LaSrNiReO
system undergoes multiple magnetic transitions, indicated by a divergence between ZFC and FC at ~255 K, typical
ions confined in a fcc sublattice, and by a down turn in magnetization at ~27 K, observed in both the
ZFC and FC curves. Transport measurements confirm purely insulating behavior of the samples. However with Ca
doping, the structure undergoes into larger monoclinic distortion, which results in a larger deviation of the Ni-O-Re
NOR) bond angles from 180°. This deviation enables substantial superexchange interaction between the Ni
orbitals, resulting to an overall ferrimagnetic order between two individual ferromagnetic sublattices.
All the samples appeared to be single phased as no impurity peak is detected in the whole 2
XRD data, collected at room temperature for LaSr
(circle), calculated (line through the data) and the difference (blue dashed line) diffraction data are shown in Fig.
0.0 and 1.0 compositions respectively, which could be fitted with the
increase in monoclinic distortion (see the insets to Fig.
) with increasing Ca concentration (see Fig. S1 in SI to
compare the XRD patterns for all the three compositions collected at a synchrotron X-ray source). The observation
of the monoclinic distortion in this series of compounds is in agreement with the calculated tolerance factors (
1.0). An overall shift of the Bragg peaks towards higher 2
a decrease of the unit cell parameters with increasing
. Presence of the intense peak at around 19.6° (1 1 0) indicates
high degree of Ni/Re ordering within the double perovskite structure of LaSr
positions. A combined refinement of XRD and NPD patterns was carried out for both the compositions at 300 K in
order to accurately quantify Ni and Re cation ordering and determine the oxygen positions. The refined structural
parameters along with the bond lengths and bond angles are given in Tables
between Ni and Re is quantified to be 96% and 99% for
1.0 from the refined occupation numbers of
Ni1/Re1 and Re2/Ni2 at (0.5, 0.0, 0.5) and (0.5, 0.0, 0.0) crystallographic sites, respectively. The stoichiometry of Ni
and Re in the compounds are probed and confirmed through ICP-OES experiments (see SI). The Bond Valence Sum
(BVS) for Ni is calculated from the Ni-O bond lengths listed in Table
. The values obtained are 2.2 for both the
composition which is in accordance with the expected oxidation state of the Ni ions in these compounds.
Next, we have performed X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) at the
-edge of Ni to further verify the charge
state. The XAS spectra collected for
. The reference spectra are obtained by digitizing and recalling the data points from the
absorption edge is superimposed with the Ni
spectral features of both the Ni
peaks indicated by the arrows in the figure. In the 2
charge state of Ni as in NiO, the lower energy peak of
geometrically frustrated face-centered cubic lattice of edge-shared tetrahedra formed by the
